channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: False Leads Set Back Search for Malaysian Jet
item.description: Authorities widen the search area after suspected debris and an oil slick turn out to be unconnected to a Malaysia Airlines flight that vanished Saturday night.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER, KEITH BRADSHER and MATTHEW L. WALD
item.media:description: A member of the military looked out of a helicopter during a search-and-rescue mission off the Tho Chu Islands of Vietnam on Monday.

item.title: For Hateful Comic in France, Muzzle Becomes a Megaphone
item.description: Despite dozens of charges, French officials have been confounded in efforts to stop the performances of Dieudonné M’bala M’bala, who is seen as anti-Semitic.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Corentin Fohlen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dieudonné M’bala M’bala has been charged with anti-hate law violations 38 times in recent years.

item.title: World Briefing: Turkish Court Orders Release of 19 More in Plot Case
item.description: The men were convicted with scores of others of plotting a coup in the Ergenekon case, which the government of Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan used to break the political power of Turkey’s military.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: World Briefing: India’s Supreme Court Orders Speedier Trials for Lawmakers
item.description: India’s Supreme Court on Monday ordered lower courts to conclude the trials of lawmakers charged with grave crimes within a year of the date of the charges being filed as a way to reduce the number of politicians who are re-elected during drawn-out trials.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: World Briefing: Thieves in Gaza Go Where Money Is, but Hamas Quickly Gets It Back
item.description: Masked gunmen robbed a post office in Gaza City on Monday, stealing what local news reports said was the equivalent of about $500,000.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM

item.title: U.S. and Russia Hit Diplomatic Roadblock Trying to Start Ukraine Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry delayed an anticipated trip to Russia and the two sides issued dueling accounts of their recent diplomacy to defuse the crisis in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Busy, but Wary, in Europe’s Steel Industry
item.description: As demand rises again, the big question is whether it will be sufficient to keep all of Europe’s steel mills running.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED and PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Daunting Tests Await Admiral Named N.S.A. Chief
item.description: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers, who currently runs the Navy’s Fleet Cyber Command, has been appointed to navigate a bureaucratic, political and public relations disaster.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:credit: Mc1 Nate Guimont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Vice Adm. Michael S. Rogers addressed students at the Center for Information Dominance in Monterey, Calif., in 2012.

item.title: Release of Syrian Nuns Was Part of a Hostage Swap
item.description: The Syrian government freed a group of detainees that included women and children in exchange for the nuns’ release by insurgents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: The captive nuns at a Mass in Damascus, Syria. For their freedom, the government released a group of women and children.

item.title: Yen-Pinching Undercuts Japan’s Push Against Years of Deflation
item.description: After years of falling prices, many Japanese have the mind-set that they need to save, not spend, putting a burden on the economy.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: As often as she can, Yusa Nishimura tucks away 500-yen coins (about $5) in a savings book.

item.title: Wendy Hughes, 61, Australian Actress, Dies
item.description: Ms. Hughes, a film, stage and television star in Australia, was known in the United States and elsewhere for her role in “My Brilliant Career” and other movies.
item.dc:creator: By MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Wendy Hughes in “Warm Nights on a Slow Moving Train” (1988), in which she played a schoolteacher turned seductress.

item.title: Roger Hilsman, Adviser to Kennedy on Vietnam, Dies at 94
item.description: Mr. Hilsman angered some military officials who felt they had been bypassed after he helped draft a cable, approved by President John F. Kennedy, giving tacit American support to a coup against President Ngo Dinh Diem of South Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Use of Stolen Passports on Missing Malaysian Airliner Highlights Air Security Flaw
item.description: Aviation safety experts said the discovery that two passengers were traveling on stolen passports has revealed a major gap in security procedures developed since the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: An Indonesian sailor scans near the Strait of Malacca. False leads have set back the search for the missing jet.

item.title: Madrid Journal: A Not-So-Quixotic Search for Cervantes
item.description: Miguel de Cervantes was buried where he wanted in 1616, but strangely there has been no effort to identify the literary giant’s grave site — until now.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Carlos Lujan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miguel de Cervantes was buried in 1616 in the Trinitarias convent in Madrid.

item.title: Russia’s Grip Tightens With Shows of Force at Ukrainian Bases
item.description: In one of several swift but thus far bloodless escalations, Russian forces raided a Ukrainian naval missile base in the darkness of early Monday.
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS and NOAH SNEIDER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pro-Russian demonstrations on Monday in Donetsk, eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Dispute Over Fate of Mysterious Tanker With Oil From Libya
item.description: The vessel, whose ownership is unclear, is believed to be carrying oil obtained illicitly from militia groups.
item.dc:creator: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Egypt Tycoon Is Released; 3 Detainees Detail Abuse
item.description: A juxtaposition of court sessions raised new alarms that Egypt was turning back to its old authoritarian ways.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Israel Watches Warily as Hezbollah Gains Battle Skills in Syria
item.description: While the Israeli military used to plan for conventional armored battle, its forces now train to withstand fighters who have antitank missiles and underground hide-outs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers trained in the Golan Heights last week. Israel has been preparing intensively for another possible round of fighting with Hezbollah.

item.title: Israel Displays Arms It Says Were Headed to Gaza
item.description: In a televised event, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel toured a display of seized weapons and munitions laid out at the naval base in the port of Eilat.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Market Slips as China’s Exports Take a Spill
item.description: China’s February drop in exports and a production setback for Boeing were offset by healthy jumps for Facebook and Alexion Pharmaceuticals.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Frequent Flier: Fruitful but Tough Adventures in the Amazon
item.description: Transportation and terrain were surmountable production challenges for the co-founder of the beverage company Runa.
item.dc:creator: By DAN MacCOMBIE

item.title: Rewriting the Menu in Tulum, Mexico
item.description: The chef Eric Werner is inventing food that is avant-garde and ancient, global and local, at his restaurant Hartwood in Tulum.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA MOSKIN
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eric Werner with Antonio May Balan, on Mr. Balan’s farm in the highlands. Corn, pumpkins, and beans grow together in the way of the Maya, who developed a system of agriculture here in about 4,000 B.C.

item.title: The Lede: Jailed Leaders of Egypt’s 2011 Revolt Describe Beatings
item.description: In a letter smuggled out of Egypt’s Tora Prison over the weekend, a leading figure in the 2011 uprising who was recently jailed for protesting the current military-backed government, reported that prisoners are routinely tortured.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: No Winner Yet in El Salvador’s Close Presidential Race
item.description: An electoral tribunal said that the narrow margin made it impossible to declare a winner between Salvador Sánchez Cerén and Norman Quijano.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Supporters of Norman Quijano, a two-term mayor of San Salvador.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Managing the Discussion of the Missing Malaysian Jet
item.description: China’s authorities are juggling public grief and anger over the disappearance of a Malaysian airliner with what they really want high in the public mind: the current session of the National People’s Congress.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Relatives of passengers on the missing flight gathered in a hotel meeting room in Beijing on Monday, awaiting information.
